BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night was good. Wind slabs above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. The hard wind slabs of recent weeks can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 3000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Significant warming to 3000 m.
The mostly small wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations over a wide area.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls at elevated altitudes. The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, on steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on weak layers in particular on shady slopes. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Until Monday the wind will be strong at times.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Until Monday the wind will be strong at times over a wide area. The fresh wind slabs will form in the vicinity of peaks. The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. Skiers can release avalanches in isolated cases, including medium-sized ones. Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m.
Older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The sometimes strong wind will transport only a little snow. As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2400 m. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The sometimes strong wind will transport only a little snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs can still be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and generally at elevated altitudes. They can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The wind slabs are to be avoided in particular in terrain where there is a danger of falling. Even a small avalanche can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry at high altitude. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly.
Low and intermediate altitudes and very steep sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like.
In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry touring conditions are mostly favourable. The snowpack will be in most cases stable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A mostly favourable avalanche situation will prevail. In the morning there is a risk of slipping on hard snow. It is advisable to bring a snow knife and crampon with you for the steeper sections.
The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible, in particular in case of releases originating from very steep sunny starting zones below approximately 2800 m that still retain some snow.
As a consequence of a strong wind from northerly directions, small wind slabs formed on Friday at high altitude. This applies in particular along the border with Switzerland.
Dry and wet avalanches can be released in near-surface layers, in particular by large additional loads. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on extremely steep slopes. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Until Tuesday the weather will be mild.
In particular steep south, west and southeast facing slopes: Towards its surface, the snowpack is hard and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. Low and intermediate altitudes and sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing softening of the old snowpack.
Below approximately 2200 m only a little snow is lying on south and southwest facing slopes. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Low avalanche danger will prevail. The conditions are favourable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The older wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines. Regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 2 (moderate): As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from northwesterly directions, small wind slabs formed at elevated altitudes. They can be released in isolated cases.

Only isolated gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. Only isolated moist avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small, in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow fell on Thursday, in particular in the north. Over a wide area strong northwesterly wind above the tree line.

The snowpack will be in most cases stable.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Intermediate and high altitudes: Early and late morning: The old snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are favourable over a wide area. The wind will be strong in some cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be stable. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Avalanches can be released in the old snowpack in particular in extremely steep terrain. This applies in particular in case of a large load. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare and are difficult to recognise.
There is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. After a clear night this applies in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Individual weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes and sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like. The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust will soften during the day.
In all regions as well as in all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
There is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. After a clear night this applies in particular.
Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the Prealps as well as at low altitude no snow is lying. Also in neighbouring regions less snow than usual is lying.
In particular adjacent to ridgelines snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The conditions are spring-like. The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust will soften during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Low avalanche danger will prevail. The conditions are favourable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

Only isolated gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. Only isolated moist avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small, in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow fell on Thursday, in particular in the north. Over a wide area strong northwesterly wind above the tree line.

The snowpack will be in most cases stable.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Intermediate and high altitudes: Early and late morning: The old snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are favourable over a wide area. The wind will be strong in some cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Significant warming to 3000 m.
The mostly small wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase in particular on steep sunny slopes. Gliding avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In particular on steep slopes individual avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions only a little snow is lying.
The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Individual gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.

As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed at elevated altitudes. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep northwest, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2200 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation dry loose snow slides are to be expected.

Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released in isolated cases and mostly by large additional loads in particular on very steep sunny slopes. This applies above approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Thursday. The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow.
Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack, in particular on very steep sunny slopes above approximately 2600 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
Low and intermediate altitudes: The old snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. Fresh wind slabs require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Until Monday the wind will be strong at times.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small moist and wet avalanches are possible.
Until Monday the wind will be strong at times over a wide area. The fresh wind slabs will form in the vicinity of peaks. The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. Older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,. The hard wind slabs are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather was mild. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2400 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The sometimes strong wind will transport only a little snow. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The sometimes strong wind will transport only a little snow.
